awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Reconfigurable Over-the-air Chamber for Wireless Device Testing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project has several facets. From the standpoint of scientific understanding, using a reverberation chamber with time-varying and non-homogeneous reflection from the walls is a new concept, and successful understanding of this technology may impact a variety of applications. More specifically for wireless device testing, the fact that the most accurate traditional testing methods for wireless device performance are costly, they are unavailable to all but the largest companies or research organizations. The development of an accurate, low-cost, and rapid testing capability levels the playing field among wireless device development organizations and introduces consumer-benefitting competition into the market. Furthermore, the low cost fosters the development of emerging technologies that may offer low initial revenue but provide high social value. Finally, because the low-cost and accurate testing capability will enable wireless device designers to improve performance and offer increased spectral efficiency, it will foster increased access to the limited radio spectrum, enabling more people to have the access to information that they need for personal and economic development. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project is motivated by the observation that emerging wireless devices must offer increased levels of sophistication in order to keep pace with the growing demand for data throughput. Achieving this objective requires development of new testing methods that can rapidly and accurately assess the effectiveness of emerging devices at a low-cost. The innovative reconfigurable over-the-air chamber (ROTAC) proposed in this work promises dramatic improvement in wireless device testing. The proposed activities focus on three key technical challenges: 1) generation of a detailed simulation model that allows detailed understanding of the behavior of a ROTAC for wireless device testing; 2) exploration of optimization algorithms that can quickly determine the reconfigurable parameters that achieve the desired channel characteristics; and 3) implementation of algorithms on an experimental ROTAC prototype. Successful completion of these activities will demonstrate the feasibility of the technology as a commercial product and enable observation of the technology limitations and strengths.

por.por_cntn:
Modern wireless devices increasingly exploit the complicated nature of electromagnetic propagation. For example, multiple antennas are used currently to increase data rates and reliability in wireless local area networks by matching the electromagnetic radiation to the multipath propagation, and such technology likely will be used in emerging cellular systems in the near future. Because the antenna system is becoming critical to device performance, over-the-air (OTA) testing of such devices has become essential, which means testing the device performance in realistic environments. 

There are two main types of OTA testing for multi-antenna devices. In multi-probe OTA testing, the device under test (DUT) is surrounded by multiple antennas - each of which is connected to a channel emulator - in an anechoic chamber. While this technique enables synthesis of a wide range of multipath channels, it can be expensive. Mode-stirred reverberation chambers offer more economical testing, although the ability to control the propagation scenario is limited.

To overcome the challenges associated with these traditional OTA testing procedures, we developed a reconfigurable over the air chamber (ROTAC) whose wall reflections can be reconfigured to control the multipath radio waves observed at the DUT. In this chamber, the walls are lined with antennas. A small number of the antennas act as feeds which are connected to test equipment (i.e. protocol tester), while the remainder are terminated with tunable reconfigurable impedance elements that control the reflections from the wall. The statistics of the fields on the DUT can be controlled by optimizing the states of the reconfigurable impedance elements. The proposed research work had three main goals.

1. Simulation Model

Our first task was to develop a comprehensive simulation model that allows us to explore quickly the range of channels that can be emulated and to test control algorithms that synthesize the desired channel characteristics. We developed three such tools:

a) a finite-difference time-domain simulation,

b) a moment method simulation, and

c) a plane wave analysis simulation.

These tools work with basic circuit analysis algorithms to determine the radio waves in the chamber for a specific set of source excitations and reconfigurable element terminations. 

2. Algorithms

Our second task was to develop algorithms for determining the impedance states of the reconfigurable elements that achieve the desired space-time channel characteristics for the simulated environment. We developed a gradient ascent optimizer seeded by a convex optimization that is highly efficient and effective in determining the optimal impedance states and excitations. This algorithm coupled with the simulation tools demonstrated that the ROTAC is capable of providing a wide range of propagation environments. 

3. Prototype Chamber

Out final task was to build a prototype chamber and test its performance using the developed algorithms. We constructed two different prototypes during the course of this project. Measurements conducted on the chamber indicate that the simulation tools were highly accurate in determining the chamber characteristics. Furthermore, these measurements were used to demonstrate the effective nature of the optimization algorithms and to confirm that the ROTAC can effectively provide a wide range of propagation environments for OTA testing of multi-antenna devices.
